A novel mixed ligand copper (׀׀) complex having 2,9-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline and nitrate has been successfully synthesized and characterized by single crystal XRD. Following synthesis, this complex was anchored on acid functionalized nano-porous materials such as MCM-41-SO3H and SBA-15-SO3H, and these hybrid materials were characterized using a variety of techniques such as FT-IR, PXRD, BET, SEM, TG, and so on. These modified mesoporous materials (MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu) were subjected to solvent-free selective benzyl alcohol oxidation with TBHP (Tert-Butyl Hydroperoxide) as an oxidant. Various reaction parameters were investigated to optimize the reaction conditions. MCM-41-SO3HCu was discovered to be an excellent catalyst in terms of benzyl alcohol conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity. Graphical abstract Novel Cu (II) complex was prepared, characterized, and immobilized in sulfonic acid functionalized MCM-41 and SBA-15 to test its effectiveness as an oxidation catalyst for the selective solvent-free oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and excellent selectivity was achieved by Copper complex modified MCM-41. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nano-porous materials Cu-complex Benzyl alcohol TBHP Oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Sustainable and practical catalytic method development for selective oxidation reactions with easily obtainable, economically viable, and atomically efficient oxidants in the fine chemical industry to obtain various intermediates and oxygen-related products is a challenging task [1–3]. Despite extensive research into homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, harmful substances are still used in the majority of the fine chemical industry, resulting in a large amount of chemical waste [4]. As a sustainable process, heterogeneous catalysis deals with the advantages of repeated use, the ease and simplicity of catalyst separation, and flexibility in continuous processing. Heterogenization of the existing homogeneous system is thus considered as the most recognized technology with respect to environmentally clean and sustainability in the use of most active oxidant, H2O2 or O2 in the contemporary industry [1–3,5–7]. Thus, to design a robust, active, and reusable oxidation catalyst is an important need in the field of basic research with industrial application. Aldehydes are important intermediates for the preparation of fragrances, drugs, vitamins, and many organic molecules, which include benzaldehyde, which is particularly significant as a precursor for agricultural, odorant, and pharmaceutical products etc. [7–12] can be produced by the selective oxidation of alcohols. It has been found in earlier literature that by altering temperature, pressure, concentration of reactants, solvents, and catalyst, etc., the reaction rate as well as the yield and characteristics of the by-products can be regulated [13,14]. A considerable effort has been made to develop a novel kind of oxidation catalyst to enhance the selectivity and yield of the desired product [8,9,15,16]. The exclusive properties of porous materials in the construction of supramolecular clusters through the capture of foreign entities lead to utilization of these assemblies in various catalysis systems. The framework structure and dimensions of the materials have the control over the geometry of the guest species it accommodates, which in turn can alter the catalytic properties of the hybrid materials as well as preserve their original properties inside the confined pores [17–21]. Schiff-base complexes based on transition metals are more sought coordination complexes, significantly used in biomedicines, biology, and catalysis etc. [22–24]. A decent number of literature is available on the use of this kind of complexes in oxidation reaction for the production of important organic molecules. These complexes are desirable due to mainly their facile preparation methods with high chemical and thermal stability [25,26–28]. The incorporation of transition metal complexes containing Schiff bases as well as phthalocyanines and porphyrins etc. have been extensively studied as heterogeneous catalysts where nano-porous solid supports are used [29–32]. Cu-complex based heterogeneous systems attract considerable attention due to the abundance of Cu metal in nature, ease of handling, stability, cheap [33–39] and thus can be used as environment friendly green oxidation catalyst. Cu-complex encapsulated hybrid solid catalysts have been found to be highly active towards oxidation reaction. Cu(II) complexes supported on polymer, bentonite based clays, zeolite Y have shown good activity for benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction [40–42]. Paula Cruz et al. have done extensive work on selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol on Cu, Cu-complexes, CuO nanoparticles incorporated porous supported hybrid catalysts [43,44]. Amine functionalized SBA-15 was used as a support to immobilize a Cu(II) Schiff base complex [45] which demonstrated superior catalytic activity in 4 h using H2O2. Further Hong Zao et.al reported the synthesis of MCM-41-immobilized bipyridine copper(I) complex [MCM-41-bpy-CuI] using aqueous ammonia as base to prepare a series of α,β- unsaturated aldehydes and aromatics [46]. There are also reports of synthesis of mimics of metalloenzymes; Al+3 and Ti+4 containing MCM-41 as a support for copper phthalocyanine (CuPc) complexes for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol [47]. A number of reports are available in the scientific fraternity on oxidation of benzyl alcohol by using Cu-based catalysts [47–51]. Cu(II) tetradentate N2O2 Schiff base complex was immobilized into amino-modified MCM-41 showed decent catalytic activity reported by Ardakani et al. [52]. Organic acid/base functionalized MCM-41 was used as an support for incorporation of Cu(II) acetate, nitrate, ethylacetoacetate, [Cu(diamine)2(NO3)2] etc. [53–56]. Mei-Ling Cheng et al. have synthesized Cu(II) pyrazoledicarboxylate coordination polymer supported MOF-1displayed high efficiency in the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde [57]. Our group has done extensive research on the preparation of transition metal complex encapsulated porous type hybrid materials for use in photocatalysis and the epoxide ring opening of a variety of oxiranes using a series of amines and alcohols [58–61]. Herein, we have extended our research on designing a mononuclear Cu-complex using 2,9-Dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline ligand. After the synthesis the Cu-complex was immobilized on sulphosilylated mesoporous matrices. This stable and efficient hybrid catalyst was used as an oxidation catalyst for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol using tert‑Butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant. The metal complex and hybrid catalyst were characterized in details and the presence of the metal complex on the surface of the porous moieties was established by combination of various techniques. Different catalytic parameters were screened so as to establish the efficiency of the hybrid materials includes time, temperature, oxidant and catalyst amount etc. Moreover, the reaction pathway of the hybrid catalysts in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde was also explored. Experimental Synthesis of complex In the synthesis process, the ligand 2,9-Dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (1.2 mmoles) (received from Sigma Aldrich, India and was used as such) was dissolved in methanol and copper(II) nitrate salt (0.6 mmoles) was added to it. The resultant liquid was stirred overnight and green precipitate was formed which was filtered, washed with methanol and kept for crystallization in a 1:1 ratio solution of methanol and chloroform. Green diamond shaped crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction was obtained through slow evaporation. The synthesis procedure is shown in Scheme 1 . Synthesis of hybrid catalyst Reported literature method was employed to prepare the porous matrices MCM-41 and SBA-15. The support materials were synthesized from well-known literature method [62]. Marcaptopropyltriethoxysilane (MPTES) was used to impart acid functionality in the solid support [63]. Cu-complex immobilization was carried out according to literature procedure. The functionalized material and Cu-complex was mixed in a particular proportion in toluene solvent with overnight stirring followed by filtration, washing and drying [59]. The modification procedure is schematically described in Scheme 2 . Catalyst characterization X-ray single crystal data for Cu-complex was collected on Bruker D8VENTURE Microfocus diffractometer equipped with PHOTON II Detector, with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å), controlled by the APEX2 software package. Raw data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects by Bruker APEX II program suite. The space group was analyzed by metric symmetry and systematic absences (determined by XPREP) were further checked by PLATON for additional symmetry [64]. All the structures were resolved using direct methods and were refined against all data in the reported 2θ ranges through full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXL program suite using the OLEX 2 interface. Hydrogen atoms were placed at idealized positions during the final refinements of each structure. Structural visualization was done using OLEX 2 interface [65–66]. Crystallographic details of Cu-complex can be obtained with CCDC 2,236,715. This can be found free of cost from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data centre through www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystallographic data and structural details of the complex are summarized in Table S1 & S2. Bruker PHASER diffractometer with graphite monochromatized CuKα radiation at 30 kV and 10 mA was used to check the phase purity of the pure and functionalized materials. Sorption analyses were carried out in a conventional volumetric apparatus (BELSORP-max, Bel Japan) at liquid nitrogen temperature. The samples were degassed at 50 °C under evacuation prior to analysis. A Hitachi S-4800 SEM coupled machine was used to calculate the size and morphology of the materials. 29Si MAS NMR spectra were measured on a Varian 600PS solid NMR spectrometer with a spinning frequency of 7 kHz. The 29Si was referenced to 3-(trimethylsilyl) propionic-2,2,3,3-d4 acid sodium salt. A Hitachi STA 7200 equipment was used for thermal analysis. In a typical procedure a definite amount of material was heated to 800 °C in presence of air. For elemental analysis, ICP-OES was performed in Thermo Scientific iCAP 6000 instrument. IR spectra were obtained on an FT-IR spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Spectrum Two) at a resolution of 4 cm−1. UV-3600Plus, Shimadzu Co., Japan instrument was used to obtain the electronic spectra of the functionalized material. The procedure for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol Benzyl alcohol was selectively oxidised to benzaldehyde using tert‑Butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant and Cu- complex modified mesoporous materials as a catalyst. Prior to the reaction, the required amount of catalyst was activated for 1 hour at 90 °C. After activation, the activated catalyst was refluxed at 85 °C in a two neck round bottom flask in presence of oxidant TBHP (12 ml). Benzyl alcohol was added in the initial five minutes of the reaction and then the reaction was refluxed for 2 hrs. After 5 min from the start of the reaction, benzyl alcohol was added. The catalyst was removed from the resulting liquid via filtering or centrifugation, and the filtrate was analysed using gas chromatography equipped with flame ionization detector (Thermo Fisher Trace-1310, TG 5 column). Results & discussion Crystal structure This complex is monomeric, according to single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, and the Cu (II) is coordinated by five donor atoms. Two neocuproine units are acting as a chelating bidentate ligand coordinating via four N atoms, from which three nitrogen atoms are at equatorial position and one nitrogen is at axial position having bond length Cu1-N1 = 2.182(3) Å, Cu1-N2 = 2.011(2) Å, Cu1-N3 = 2.003(3) Å and Cu1-N4 = 2.101(3) Å. The coordination of copper is completed by oxygen atom of nitrate ion that is in axial position having bond length Cu1-O1 = 2.047(2) Å. As a result, the geometry of the copper (II) center is pentacoordinated. The geometry of pentacoordinated complexes is completely described by the geometry index or structural parameter tau (τ), where τ = β – α / 60 in which β and α are the two largest L–M–L angles of the coordination sphere [67–68]. The geometry is distorted trigonal bipyramidal when the value is between 0.5 and 1, and it is distorted square pyramidal when the value is between 0 and 0.5. The observed τ value of 0.56 suggests a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the copper (II) ion. Fig. 1 shows the ternary mononuclear complex's molecular structure, while Table S1 and S2 provide a summary of crystallographic details and some of the bonds' lengths and angles. Structural investigation of hybrid materials The prepared hybrid materials were thoroughly characterized by a series of instrumental methods. For confirming the structural integrity, phase purity and presence of foreign entities powder XRD was performed which is depicted in Fig. 2 . From the XRD of both the materials it is clear that from pure material (p in each figure) to acid functionalization (y) to metal complex immobilized catalysts there are clear decrease of peak intensities after the each modifications, is in good agreement of uptake of guest functionality and this is due to decrease of the scattering contrast between pore wall and pore [69]. In order to check for metal complex signal, powder XRD-diagrams of the composite have been recorded up to 50° 2θ but no additional diffraction peak was observed. This is in agreement with the expected line broadening with high disorder as well as evenly distribution of the complex molecules onto the surface of guest supports [70]. Sorption analysis by nitrogen is explained in Fig. 3 , S1 and Table 1 . The BET surface areas of acid functionalized MCM-41 and SBA-15 were determined to 600 m²/g and 534 m²/g respectively with 1.88 and 5 nm pore diameter and 0.94 cm³/g and 0.89 cm³/g pore volume respectively. After metal complex incorporation significant decrease in surface area and other textural properties were noticed. This is in agreement with data published in the literature and confirms the good quality of the MCM-41 and SBA-15 sample. After metal complex immobilization reduction of all surface properties were observed is an indication of successful incorporation of guest functionalities onto the silica base. FT-IR was also performed to identify the guest moieties in the hybrid silica material and is depicted in Fig. 4 . At around 1100 and 500 cm−1 two peaks were identified in acid functionalized and Cu-complex modified materials, attributed to Si-O-Si stretching originated from silicate framework. Bands at around 540 and 600 cm−1 in the FTIR spectrum can be allotted to the vibrations of Cu(II)-O bonds [71]. The peak at 600 cm−1 in the Cu-complex modified material, which is the characteristic of Cu-O bond formation. Some small fringes have appeared at 400–540 cm−1 may be attributed to the Cu-N bond [72]. The existence of peaks due to aromatic ring vibrations in the range of 1300–1600 cm−1 and C=N stretching vibration at around 1650 cm−1 [73] are observed in both the modified materials, confirming the tethering of the Cu-based complex onto the surfaces of functionalized MCM-41 and SBA-15. 29Si NMR of Cu-complex modified MCM-41 and SBA-15 catalysts is depicted in Fig. 5 . Two signals appeared at around -100 ppm and -110 ppm are allotted as [Si(OSi)3(OH)] Q3 and [Si(OSi)4] Q4 structures [74,75]. The peak at around -90 ppm, which is for Q2 resonance is very less in both the materials. Apart from these, a few broad peaks are observed at around -50 and -70 ppm assigned to T2 and T3 structures, which may come from carbon-silicon bonds further confirming the successful anchoring of sulfonic acid functional group onto the surface of mesoporous silicas. 29Si MAS-NMR spectra of pure MCM-41 is compared with MCM-41-SO3HCu, which is supplied as supplementary information (Fig. S6), where the decrease in the intensity of Q2 and Q3 supports the tethering of foreign moieties. UV–visible spectra are shown in Fig. 6 . The UV of Cu-complex modified catalysts were compared with Cu-complex only. In the region of 200–310 nm pure Cu- complex (y spectra in Fig. 5) shows ligand-to-metal charge transfer transitions (LMCT). Another low intensity absorption band observed at 330–400 nm may be due to d-d transition. All the characteristic peaks are observed in Cu-complex modified catalysts as well (x spectra), however, there is a clear red shift of around 50 nm in the absorption band in the modified material. To check the thermal stability, TG analysis was also carried out for the hybrid materials, which is given in Fig. S2. The TG of Cu-complex modified silica was compared with that of pure Cu complex (Fig. S1 Z). From 197 to 523 °C, four steps with an 81 percent weight loss were discovered in the Cu-complex. However, after immobilization in mesoporous silica, the thermal stability of the modified materials was noticeably enhanced with a 7% weight loss in 350–500 °C range. Catalytic activity test Comparison of various catalysts The selective oxidation reaction of benzyl alcohol was demonstrated (Fig. 7 ) by comparing the catalytic results of pure materials like SBA-15, MCM-41, acid functionalized (SBA-15-SO3H, MCM-41-SO3H) and copper complex anchored (SBA-15-SO3HCu and MCM-41-SO3HCu) as well as the blank reaction (without catalyst). At 85 °C, 40 mg of catalyst were utilized in each reaction. When compared to copper complex anchored materials, pure SBA-15, MCM-41, and only acid functionalized exhibited minimal catalytic activity. Additionally, when the reaction was run without a catalyst, only 7% conversion was discovered. Conversion and selectivity using pure SBA-15 were reported to be 9 and 67%, and 8 and 63%, respectively, for SBA-15-SO3H. After the inclusion of the copper complex on SBA-15, the conversion of benzyl alcohol was almost doubled. Likewise, conversion and selectivity using pure MCM-41 were reported to be 9 and 66%, and 7 and 67%, respectively, for MCM-41-SO3H. After the inclusion of the copper complex on MCM-41, the conversion of benzyl alcohol was boosted by 32–34%, and the selectivity for benzaldehyde was raised by 15%. The inclusion of the copper complex dramatically improved conversion and selectivity. Effect of catalyst amount To evaluate the effect of catalyst concentration on the reaction at specific reaction parameters, the catalyst amount of MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu varied from 30 to 80 mg in the initial screening as depicted in Fig. 8 . In comparison to MCM-41-SO3HCu, SBA-15-SO3HCu demonstrated marginal catalytic activity. At 40 mg catalyst amount, benzyl alcohol conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity were found to be relatively reasonable, with 41% and 19% conversion and 82% and 63% selectivity for MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu, respectively. The effect of oxidant amount The effect of oxidant (TBHP) amount on the oxidation of benzyl alcohol had also been investigated. The oxidant amount was varied from 10 ml to 20 ml (Fig. 9 ). For MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu, the benzyl alcohol conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity were found to be 28% and 17% conversion and 82% and 65% selectivity, respectively, at 10 mL oxidant quantity. At a dosage of 12 mL of oxidant, it increases further to 41% and 19% conversion and 82% and 63% selectivity, and it was discovered that at larger doses of oxidant, 15 and 20 mL, the conversion and selectivity decline. The results show a direct relationship between benzaldehyde selectivity and the amount of TBHP used. At lower concentrations, it produces insufficient oxygen for benzyl alcohol to oxidize. While an excess of TBHP produces more oxygen ions, which are responsible for the further oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. Therefor, 12 mL of TBHP was considered as optimum amount of oxidant. Effect of temperature Fig. 10 depicts the effect of temperature ranging from 85 to 100 °C on benzyl alcohol oxidation. Temperature increases the conversion of benzyl alcohol, but decreases the selectivity of benzaldehyde. For MCM-41-SO3HCu, it was observed that on increasing the temperature, the conversion was increased but selectivity decreased i.e. at 100 °C, the conversion was 43% and the selectivity was 70%. Here we can observe that the selectivity is very less compared to the conversion and selectivity at 85 °C which was found to be 40% and 82% respectively. Thus, it can be concluded that the optimized temperature for the aforesaid reaction is 85 °C for MCM-41-SO3HCu. For SBA-15-SO3HCu, at 100 °C, the conversion was 23% and selectivity was 65%. Here we can observe that the selectivity is less compared to the conversion and selectivity at 90 °C which was found to be 22% and 68% respectively. Thus, it can be concluded that the optimized temperature for the said reaction is 90 °C for SBA-15-SO3HCu. Effect of reaction time The reaction kinetics were also investigated and are shown in Fig. 11 . The oxidation reaction time was varied from 2 to 4 h. With increase in reaction time, there are slight changes in the benzyl alcohol conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity, so 2 h is considered an optimal reaction time for this oxidation reaction. A comprehensive literature review of the several catalysts utilized for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol where conversion for benzyl alcohol and selectivity for benzaldehyde are considered is presented in Table 2 . Lili Liu et al. utilized series of Au–Ni bimetallic alloy with Au:Ni mole ratio varying from 1:0.35 to 1:4.76 supported by a metal–organic framework MIL-101 for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol, 99% selectivity and 84% conversion was achieved using THF solvent [77]. Norasidah Mohd JamJam et al. have shown 19% conversion and 80% selectivity using nanoparticles of bimetallic gold palladium supported on TiO2 [78]. Paula Cruz et al. reported 73% conversion and 54% selectivity utilizing Cu/IMIL-SBA-15-G1 catalyst synthesized by immobilization of Cu(II)-IMIL complex and followed by chemical reduction method [44]. There are reports on employing Au/CuOco, Al-MCM-41(10)-CuPc(4), Cu-S-SBA-15, CuAc-DAPyPTS-MCM-41, and many more materials for selective benzyl alcohol oxidation. According to the previous literature review, high conversion and selectivity were achieved in our case utilizing MCM-41-SO3HCu in a relatively short time and without the need of any solvent, demonstrating the uniqueness and efficacy of the modified material. Mechanism A schematic presentation of hypothesized mechanistic pathway for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol with the MCM-41-SO3HCu catalyst was described in Scheme 4 . The sixth empty site of the penta coordinated copper complex is where a TBHP is attached to start the catalytic cycle, creating the hexa coordinated transition state. Benzyl alcohol is then oxidised by the peroxo hexa-coordinated intermediate species, releasing one tert‑BuOH molecule in the process. This intermediate then yields benzaldehyde and H2O, regenerating the penta-coordinated complex [76]. Reusability test The experimental results of recycled MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu catalysts are shown in Fig. 12(A and B). The solid catalyst was recovered by centrifugation at the end of each cycle, washed with ethanol, and dried. At the end of each oxidation reaction, the catalyst was recycled up to three times without alteration. The selectivity of benzyl alcohol was found to be almost constant for both the cases but the reactant conversion decreased significantly. The Sheldon test was used to verify the heterogeneity of the prepared MCM-41-SO3HCu catalyst. In this test, the reaction was initiated under optimized circumstances, and after 1 hour, the catalyst was filtered out from the reaction mixture and the reaction was continued for another 1 hour. As demonstrated in Fig. 12(C), there was a modest increase in conversion up to 33% from 29% (at 1 hr) even after the catalyst was removed however it is lower than the actual conversion with catalyst (41%). The results show that active site leaching into the reaction media occurs along the reaction course. Figs. S3 and S4 show the XRD patterns and FT-IR analysis of the pure as well as reused catalyst. It is anticipated that this was due to deactivation of the catalyst, irreversible binding of the molecules onto the active sites and leaching of the copper complex, a relatively common occurrence reported by many researchers [44,77] and confirmed by FT-IR analysis of the pure complex and reaction mixture (Fig. S5). Conclusion A novel copper neocuproine based mono-nuclear coordination complex was successfully synthesized and characterized by single crystal XRD. The Cu(II) center in the complex found to be penta–coordinated in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. This copper complex was anchored on acid functionalized MCM-41and SBA-15. Subsequently, thorough characterization was performed to confirm the presence of the guest moiety in the support material, as well as to determine the material's morphology, surface area, presence of functional groups, crystallinity, and phase purity. The well described hybrid material was evaluated for solvent free selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol using aqueous TBHP and excellent conversion of benzyl alcohol and selectivity for benzaldehyde was found by using hybrid MCM-41 catalyst in compared to SBA-15. The Si/Cu ratio after modification was high in SBA-15 than MCM-41 as revealed by ICP analysis which indicates the less incorporation of Cu-complex in SBA-15 material and further reflected in the catalytic activity. The prepared hybrid catalyst can also be explored in other industrially important reactions. CRediT authorship contribution statement Parikshit Paredi: Methodology, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: A novel mixed ligand copper (׀׀) complex having 2,9-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline and nitrate has been successfully synthesized and characterized by single crystal XRD. Following synthesis, this complex was anchored on acid functionalized nano-porous materials such as MCM-41-SO3H and SBA-15-SO3H, and these hybrid materials were characterized using a variety of techniques such as FT-IR, PXRD, BET, SEM, TG, and so on. These modified mesoporous materials (MCM-41-SO3HCu and SBA-15-SO3HCu) were subjected to solvent-free selective benzyl alcohol oxidation with TBHP (Tert-Butyl Hydroperoxide) as an oxidant. Various reaction parameters were investigated to optimize the reaction conditions. MCM-41-SO3HCu was discovered to be an excellent catalyst in terms of benzyl alcohol conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Mononuclear Cu-complex embedded ordered nano-porous silica based hybrid catalyst for oxidation of benzyl alcohol
